User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.6) Gecko/20040206 Firefox/0.8
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.6) Gecko/20040206 Firefox/0.8

If I set the src of an IFrame (or Object I suppose) to a URL outside my site
then I am unable to access to content of the IFrame, even though it is owned by
my page.

I would expect to be able to access and modify the content of an IFrame
no-matter where it comes from.

I would not expect to be able to access 'pritate' information relating to the
IFrame content, such as cookekies.

IFrames seem fairly useles unless the parent document can access the content.








Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce:

<html>
<script language="javascript">
function resizeiframe(obj){
	obj=document.getElementById(obj);
	objContentDocument = obj.contentWindow.document;
	objContentBody = objContentDocument.body;
	obj.height=objContentBody.scrollHeight;	

}
</script>
<body onload="resizeiframe('header');">
<iframe id="header" src="http://slashdot.org/"></iframe>
</body>
</html>
Actual Results:  
cannot find out the height of the iframe content

Expected Results:  
returned the height of the iframe content

comments.raw_text:
Cross-site scripting is bad, period.  There's so many ways this could be abused,
and has been abused, that all access is deliberately blocked by all browsers I
am aware of.

Not a bug, this is intended behaviour for security reasons.

comments.raw_text:
I would say it's a bug.

I keep my child on a leash, just in case he wanders anywhere dangerous, I've
seen other children do stupid things and I don't want mine to follow.

Should I raise another bug that security isn't fine grained enough to allow
secure cross-site scripting?

The owner should have access to the content, except secure content, the owner
should be able to change the content but any script changes to the content
should have the security context of the owner.

 e.g. If I[the owner] insert an extra row into a table there isn't a security
problem. If I make any changes to the script then those changes should run in
the security context of the owner.


I realise that this requires that all script elements will require an extra
property for security, which shouldn't really be that hard to do. 

if element.security then set security = element.secutiry else set security =
element.parent.security.
